channel.title: davewiner tweets

item.description: NBA fans: Nets or Celtics?

Self-moderation is going to be a huge deal. Maybe to make something workable you have to start something nÃ©w, not in a half assed way. How about a Twitter-like webservice at AWS. Let a thousand Twitters bloom. Interop baked in from the beginning.
Ukrainian Tractors Versus Russian Armor. https://t.co/bc2diz4es7
@WVTechie99 @elonmusk I would definitely have a problem with that.
Whatâ€™s the real argument in favor of Musk buying Twitter? https://t.co/ew2gCDLEhY

@dbfarber @TechmemeChatter @mmasnick Hi Dan, I think thatâ€™s wrong. I own a Tesla and the human factors are everything. The car is driving for me, if I donâ€™t control it, I would never let it drive.
What Will Happen if Russia Defaults on Its Debt? https://t.co/0WvIN4f0Yf
@tailorvj @mattbirchler Sorry, I didnâ€™t know. Can you point me to @ web3 page I can look at? Iâ€™d love to see. I remember the thrill when I visited my first web page on my Mac in 1994.
Has @jack said anything about @elonmusk wanting to buy Twitter?

An idea for @elonmusk. It's possible you can do everything you want by building on the Twitter API.
Regardless, if you manage to own Twitter, you should reserve some serious resources to invest in developer products. It's a completely untapped thing. Unbelievable how much value there is locked up in an internet-scale notification system with a user-friendly interface.
API + UI + scale.
BTW, come to think of it, why doesn't @bluesky start working at the API level. Why focus on reinventing the communication layer. What twitter has is incredible. It works, and the people who own the platform aren't shitheads.
A good day to bookmark https://t.co/6xgUEpITJU.
PayPalâ€™s Peter Thiel is not a genius. (I rewrote JN's headline, it needed it.) https://t.co/we5Ur1Mzu6
Today it is totally possible to OD on NBA.

free speech is great, but there's no requirement that anyone listen. he challenge of our online systems is to learn what we want to know and find it for us. my tesla doesn't drive for me, it learns what i want it to do and tries to do it.
@FasterAnswer that's a good idea. and an algorithm could do a sort for you.
Twitter could use the smarts of my Tesla Model 3. It could let me do moderation for myself the same way I tell my car how I want it to drive. Something to think about.
@FasterAnswer You do have them -- in a proactive way -- with lists.
Wordle 301 4/6 â¬œðŸŸ¨â¬œâ¬œâ¬œ â¬œâ¬œâ¬œâ¬œðŸŸ¨ â¬œâ¬œâ¬œðŸŸ¨â¬œ ðŸŸ©ðŸŸ©ðŸŸ©ðŸŸ©ðŸŸ©

A very compelling thread about moderation. Read it you'll learn a lot. I did. https://t.co/nnpfBCX5EG
I had some experience with this in the early days of blogging and I ran away. I didn't want the job of keeping the peace in an online network.
But if @elonmusk wants it, I say give it to him. He's smart and tireless, and relatively young, and he has ideas. I think he'd be good at it.
I also think lurking in the whole mess is an answer. A way to let people have full control of what they are exposed to.
Centralized moderation is a thankless job that no one should want, and it's also expensive. The goal should be to get tech companies out of the business of moderating, and giving more tools to the people.

Listening to @billbrowder on NPR. Asked what if Russia uses a "tactical" nuclear weapon against Ukraine, what then? He hems and haws and says basically we do nothing. So now Putin has nuked a Ukrainian city (presumably) maybe a small one, and we let it pass? Really?
Also, once Russia has used a tactical nuke, how long before North Korea nukes a city, feeling ignored, and wanting some love from the US.
Even worse, just threatening to use a nuke might be enough to get NK to use one. Which Russia has already done.

1/4 Blogging and mail lists are opposites.
2/4 With a blog you can write what you like, but the challenge is getting anyone to listen.
3/4 On a mail list almost anything you say will erupt in flames, but everyone will hears everything everyone says.
4/4 Twitter and Facebook are hybrids, they have features of both.

@elonmusk @yishan Yes. And titles, simple styling, links and podcasts.
